awd_titl_txt: Mechanism and Design of Elastomeric Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract: 

Elastin is nature's most abundant elastomer. It is the durable, self-assembling protein that is responsible for the elasticity of skin, veins, arteries and lungs. It has stimulated the design of proteins that perform a variety of functions that include protein purification, targeted drug delivery, matrices for tissue engineering and hydrogels with strain-dependent conductivities. The goal of this project is to understand the principles that account for elastin's mechanical properties and to use this knowledge to design new elastomeric materials with properties that can be optimized for a particular use. To achieve this, this project spans three academic disciplines (chemistry, physics and mechanical engineering) and uses a range of contemporary methodologies including spectroscopy, structural biology and materials characterization. This provides a multidisciplinary training environment for three graduate and four high school students at the University of Louisville and the City College of New York. Both institutions draw on students from urban locations with significant percentages of minority undergraduates.


Technical Abstract: 

The objectives of this research are to understand the principles that account for elastin's essential property, recoil, and to design new elastomers. We will apply a combination of NMR and thermo-mechanics to natural elastin and to expressed polyproteins that mimic elastin's modular structure, (HX)n, where H and X are hydrophobic and cross-link modules. To simplify NMR and mutational studies, expressed proteins have modules with repeat sequences based on naturally occurring quasi-repeats. To study stretch induced solvent ordering at the protein surface, we use MQ NMR, and to study stretch induced ordering of the protein, we measure NMR relaxation times and residual shielding anisotropies at labeled sites in the protein backbone. To characterize macroscopic properties, the Young's modulus and the free energy or entropy of stretch will be measured thermo-mechanically and these are related to the NMR studies with statistical mechanical modeling to guide the design of new elastomers with altered sequences. Three graduate and four high school students will be trained and introduced to contemporary techniques that span physics, chemistry and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project include the design and expression of simplified proteins that mimic the modular repeat structure of natural elastin and retain its key biological function, elastic recoil. To understand the molecular basis for elastic recoil in elastin, we have used solution and solid state NMR of natural and designed elastins. To bridge the gap between molecular and macroscopic properties, the thermo-mechanical properties of natural and synthetic elastins were also studied. Combined, they have allowed us to understand elastin’s mechanical properties in terms of its molecular structure and dynamics. This provides the basis for the systematic design of new elastomers. 

Our results show that the alanine-rich crosslinking domains of elastin have partially helical structure, but only when capped by proline-rich hydrophobic domains. This facilitates the formation of the cross-linked network in the mature elastic matrix. The hydrophobic domains, composed of prominent 6-residue repeats VPGVGG and APGVGV found in natural elastin, are random coil and devoid of a unique structure. Compared to other intrinsically disordered proteins, these proteins are more compact and constrict by up to 30 percent in volume when the temperature is increased from 15°C to 40°C. This property is often observed in non-biological polymers, and indicates that temperature-driven constriction is a new type of protein structural change that is the physical basis for elastin's biological functions of hydrophobic-driven assembly and elastic recoil. Novel experiments using multiple quantum 2H NMR show an ~10-fold stretch induced increase in water ordering in natural bovine elastin. This is due to the hydrophobic effect and was confirmed by showing that water ordering increases as temperature is raised and by the effect of a Hoffmeister ion that alters both the hydrophobic effect and elastin's mechanical properties.

To summarize, our molecular level results put to rest all previous models that indicate 2° structure in elastin hydrophobic modules. Our results also show a weak helical structure in cross-link modules that promotes the formation of elastin’s unique crosslink structures. Companion studies with natural elastin fibers confirm that hydrophobic forces play a significant role in elastin recoil. We anticipate that continued research along these lines with cross-linked materials prepared from larger minielastin constructs will yield new materials that far exceed the robustness of current elastomers.

Four graduate students were supported in this project. Kelley Greenland (CCNY) completed her doctoral thesis and now works in the biotech industry. Jonathan Preston (CCNY), is in the middle of his doctoral studies. Two students at the University of Louisville, Faye Carvajal and Nour Jamhawi, initiated their doctoral research work at the beginning of the project. They are now in candidacy and will complete degrees within 18 months. Vahid Tahneshin (WPI, graduate student) has carried out the thermo-mechanical studies.
